name: Kokyangwuti
description:
Kokyangwuti is the Hopi name for the Spider Grandmother or Spider Woman, a major importance deity from the cosmology of different First Nations from the north american continent, especially northwestern Mexico / southwestern US.

A.k.a Na'ashjé'ii Asdzáá, her name in Diné (Navajo). In the Diné Bahane' (main account of the traditional Diné cosmology), she is the protector of humans, who introduced the spindle and the loom, and, by teaching our ancestors how to weave, she protected us from the winter. She also aided the twins Naayéé' Neizgháni (Monster Slayer) & Tobadazischini (Born of Water) in defeating the Anaye, who threatened the people from Earth's surface.

In the traditional Hopi cosmology, Kokyangwuti cared for the first people in the cavernous Tokpella, the first era of the world. The Spider Woman is also present in the traditional cosmology of the A:shiwi (Zuni) people.

Original sketch, drawing, digital painting, illustration and animation by zamahel
